{{Infobox spaceflight | name = USA-178 | image = GPS-IIR.jpg | image_caption = A Block IIR GPS satellite | insignia = | mission_type = [[Navigation satellite|Navigation]] | operator = [[US Air Force]] | COSPAR_ID = 2004-023A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=2004-023A|title=Navstar 55|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=11 July 2012}} | SATCAT = 28361 | mission_duration = 10 years (planned) | spacecraft = | spacecraft_type = [[GPS Block IIR]] | spacecraft_bus = [[AS-4000]] | manufacturer = [[Lockheed Martin]] | launch_mass = {{convert|2032|kg}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|23 June 2004, 22:54:00|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = {{nowrap|[[Delta II]] 7925-9.5,}} D305 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|SLC-17B]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | orbit_slot = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Medium Earth orbit|Medium Earth]]
([[Semi-synchronous orbit|Semi-synchronous]]) | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|20089|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|20277|km}} | orbit_inclination = 55 degrees | orbit_period = 718 minutes | apsis = gee }} '''USA-178''', also known as '''GPS IIR-12''' and '''GPS SVN-60''', is an [[United States|American]] [[navigation satellite]] which forms part of the [[Global Positioning System]]. It was the twelfth [[GPS Block IIR|Block IIR]] GPS satellite to be launched, out of thirteen in the original configuration, and twenty one [[GPS Block IIRM|overall]]. It was built by [[Lockheed Martin]], using the [[AS-4000]] [[satellite bus]]. USA-178 was launched at 22:54:00 UTC on 23 June 2004, atop a [[Delta II]] carrier rocket, flight number D305, flying in the 7925-9.5 configuration.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=11 July 2012}} The launch took place from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|Space Launch Complex 17B]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html|title=Launch List|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Launch Vehicle Database|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=11 July 2012}} and placed USA-178 into a transfer orbit. The satellite raised itself into [[medium Earth orbit]] using a [[Star-37FM]] [[apogee motor]].{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/navstar-2r.htm|title=GPS-2R (Navstar-2R)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=11 July 2012}} By 23 August 2004, USA-178 was in an orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|20089|km}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|20277|km}}, a [[orbital period|period]] of 718 minutes, and 55 degrees of [[inclination]] to the equator.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=11 July 2012}} It is used to broadcast the PRN 23 signal, and operates in slot 4 of plane F of the GPS constellation. The satellite has a mass of {{convert|2032|kg}}, and a design life of 10 years. As of 2012 it remains in service. ==References== {{reflist}} {{GPS satellites}} {{Orbital launches in 2004}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2004]] [[Category:GPS satellites]] [[Category:USA satellites]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = USA-64 | image = | image_caption = | insignia = | mission_type = [[Navigation satellite|Navigation]] | operator = [[US Air Force]] | COSPAR_ID = 1990-088A | SATCAT = 20830 | mission_duration = 7.5 years (planned) | spacecraft = | spacecraft_type = [[GPS Block II]] | manufacturer = [[Rockwell International|Rockwell]] | launch_mass = {{convert|840|kg}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|1 October 1990, 21:56:00|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = {{nowrap|[[Delta II|Delta II 6925]],}} D199 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|LC-17A]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = {{end-date|14 March 2007}} | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Medium Earth orbit|Medium Earth]]
([[Semi-synchronous orbit|Semi-synchronous]]) | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|19972|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|20390|km}} | orbit_inclination = 54.9 degrees | orbit_period = 717.94 minutes | apsis = gee }} '''USA-64''', also known as '''GPS II-9''' and '''GPS SVN-15''', was an [[United States|American]] [[navigation satellite]] which formed part of the [[Global Positioning System]]. It was the last of nine [[GPS Block II|Block II]] GPS satellites to be launched, which were the first operational GPS satellites to fly. It was also the last Block II satellite to be retired from service. USA-64 was launched at 21:56:00 UTC on 1 October 1990, atop a [[Delta II]] carrier rocket, flight number D199, flying in the 6925 configuration.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} The launch took place from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|Launch Complex 17A]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html|title=Launch List|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Launch Vehicle Database|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} and placed USA-64 into a transfer orbit. The satellite raised itself into [[medium Earth orbit]] using a [[Star-37XFP]] [[apogee motor]].{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/navstar-2.htm|title=GPS-2 (Navstar-2)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=10 July 2012}} On 31 October 1990, USA-64 was in an orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|19972|km}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|20390|km}}, a [[orbital period|period]] of 717.94 minutes, and 54.9 degrees of [[inclination]] to the equator.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} It operated in slot 5 of plane D of the GPS constellation.{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/project/navstar.htm|title=Navstar|publisher=[[Encyclopedia Astronautica]]|first=Mark|last=Wade|accessdate=10 July 2012}} The satellite had a mass of {{convert|840|kg}}, and generated 710 watts of power.{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1990-088A|title=Navstar 2-09|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=10 July 2012}} It had a design life of 7.5 years, and ceased operations on 14 March 2007, having been removed from active service on 17 November 2006 for testing. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{GPS satellites}} {{Orbital launches in 1990}} [[Category:GPS satellites]] [[Category:USA satellites]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1990]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}
